bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Vernon McKenzie, September 22, 1956

div1.p: Hench inquires if the army has any information about Hanberry's desertion from the army.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Vernon McKenzie, September 22, 1956
div1.opener:
September 22, 1956
Major Vernon McKenzie
Personnel Division
Surgeon General's Office
Department of the Army
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Major McKenzie:
div1.p:
Next Friday noon I leave Rochester to visit Mr. James L. Hanberry in Orange-
burg, South Carolina. I will spend next Saturday with him and then go to
Chattanooga where I am to speak. As you may remember, Mr. Hanberry is the
only surviving member of Walter Reed's group of human guinea pigs. I think
you know that I have made the story of the conquest of yellow fever an in-
tensive hobby for eighteen years and am writing a book on it. I have many
questions to ask Mr. Hanberry, most of which are more important than the
question about which I am writing you.

It is a matter of official record that Mr. Hanberry deserted from the Army
about eight days after re-enlistment. This is recorded in many places.
For example, on page 28 of Senate Document 822, 61st Congress, 3rd Session
(1911); on page 6 of Report No. 1429, 70th Congress, 1st Session. H.R. (1928);
on page 7 of Report No. 841, 71st Congress, 2nd Session (1930), H.R., etc.

In the Roll of Honor, published annually in the “Army Register” there is a
very brief account of Hanberry's military career: “Born South Carolina,
12 December 1875. Private, Company L, 1st South Carolina Volunteer Infantry;
service 21 August 1898 to 10 November 1898. Private, Hospital Corps, 13 Decem-
ber, 1898 to 12 December 1901. Developed experimental yellow fever February 9,
1901.” Presumably his third term began on 28 March 1902, and eight days later,
on April 4, 1902, he deserted “At the General Hospital, Washington Barracks, D.C.”
There must have been some curious reason that made him desert from an Army hos-
pital eight days after what was apparently his third enlistment, and one suspects
that he may have rebelled against some incident at the hospital. The wording
of Senate Document 822 gives one the impression that he deserted while a patient
at the Washington Barracks General Hospital, but perhaps he was not a patient
but a member of the hospital corps there. Presumably he disappeared for a
number of years but because of his outstanding service during the experiments,
the Army made no attempt to find him and after the 1928 awards (Congressional
Medal, pension and so on), he reappeared and has been honored ever since.

Now Major McKenzie, if the Army records explain his desertion, I will not ask
him about it. Could I get this information either from you (I believe you have
the records of all these men), or from the AGO? If you do not have an adequate
explanation, I think that he owes it to himself to give one before it is too
late and next Saturday, after asking other more important questions, I will ask
him very diplomatically and delicately if he cares to tell me the circumstances
Major Vernon McKenzie - 2 - September 22, 1956
of his leaving the service. I am perfectly willing for him to put the best face
on it. No one cares to embarrass him and in view of his great service, he
deserves to have the incident forgotten, except that, whether he likes it or
not (and he does) he has become a historical figure, a participant in a dramatic
development which will be written about indefinitely; hence my contention that
he should give us (you, me) whatever explanation he chooses to make.

Will you kindly wire me collect, to reach me at my home, 517 Fourth Street S.W.,
Rochester, any time before Friday morning, September 28. If I get an ex-
planation, and if he is willing for me to put it on his Army records, I will
certainly send it to you.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
